title: Building Your First Minimal API (The Data Menu)
simplifierConcept:
Imagine a food delivery app:
• BROWSE menu (GET /api/menu)
• VIEW item details (GET /api/menu/5)
• ADD to cart (POST /api/cart)
• UPDATE quantity (PUT /api/cart/3)
• REMOVE from cart (DELETE /api/cart/3)

Each of these is an API ENDPOINT! Together they form your API.

MINIMAL API (ASP.NET Core 8 style):
• NO controllers needed!
• Define endpoints directly in Program.cs
• Lambda functions handle requests
• Less boilerplate, more productivity

In-memory data store:
• For learning, use List<T> as database
• In production, you'd use real database (next module!)

Think: Minimal API = 'Quick, simple way to expose data and functionality over HTTP!'

syntaxBreakdown.explanation: Returns 200 OK status with data. 'Results' class has helpers: Ok, NotFound, BadRequest, Created, NoContent. Proper HTTP status codes!
Returns 404 Not Found status. Use when resource doesn't exist. Better than returning null!
LINQ method returns first match or null. Use 'is not null' pattern matching to check. Modern C# syntax!
List<T> simulates database for learning. Changes persist during app lifetime. Restarting app resets data. Use real DB in production!

challenge.instructions:
Build a Book Library API!

1. Create a 'Book' class:
   - int Id
   - string Title
   - string Author
   - int Year
   - bool IsAvailable

2. Create in-memory List with 4-5 books

3. Create these endpoints:
   - GET /api/books -> Return all books
   - GET /api/books/{id} -> Return single book (use Results.Ok or Results.NotFound)
   - GET /api/books/available -> Return only available books
   - GET /api/books/author/{author} -> Return books by specific author
   - GET /api/books/stats -> Return statistics (total books, available, unavailable)

4. Print endpoint list when API starts
challenge.hint: Class inside Program.cs: 'class Book { properties }'. List: 'new List<Book> { new Book { ... } }'. Find: '.FirstOrDefault()'. Filter: '.Where()'. Return: 'Results.Ok()' or 'Results.NotFound()'.
commonStickingPoints: Route order matters: /api/books/available MUST come BEFORE /api/books/{id}! Otherwise {id} matches \"available\" as ID. Specific routes before parameterized ones!
Case sensitivity in string compare: author == \"Orwell\" won't match \"orwell\"! Use .Equals(author, StringComparison.OrdinalIgnoreCase) for case-insensitive matching.
Null reference on FirstOrDefault: Always check 'is not null' before using! FirstOrDefault returns null if not found. Accessing properties on null = NullReferenceException.
Forgetting to return Results: Just returning 'null' gives 204 No Content! Use 'Results.NotFound()' for proper 404 status. HTTP status codes matter for API consumers!
